description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 25, 2020: With Bulletin N. 90, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended a meeting with EU Health Commissioner, Stella Kyriakides, and the Ministers of Health of those countries bordering with Italy: Austria, France, Slovenia and Switzerland. The Ministers of Health of Germany and Croatia also took part in the meeting. The aim of the meeting was to share and discuss information about the epidemiological situations of COVID-19 in the States. Issues about travelling and movement of goods between countries were also discussed.

description: August 24, 2020, School starts in Croatia on September 7, the Education Ministry said on Monday that the main rule is to keep one's distance, not to mix pupils from different classes and to step up hygiene, while face masks will be mandatory only for pupils in higher grades if there is not enough space for them to keep their distance. Pupils should come into contact with a few teachers as possible during one day or period. If there are no other possibilities, it is suggested that the school operates in shifts. For instance, half of the classes could attend school for one week, and the second half next week. In the event of a child exhibiting symptoms, he or she is separated from others and parents come to pick up their child, but there is no need to panic, and an epidemiologist should only be contacted if several children start showing symptoms. If a child tests positive for COVID-19, the entire class or kindergarten group will undergo self-isolation. classes in lower grades of primary school would follow the bubble model so pupils will not leave the classroom, they will have controlled access to the toilet, their teacher will be with them all the time and they will not mix with children from other classes. They will not have to wear face masks, nor will their teacher. Pupils in higher grades of primary schools will only have to wear masks if there is not enough space for them to maintain physical distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 10, 2020, Science and Education Minister Blazenka Divjak on Wednesday presented a draft distance education action plan for the next school year, saying distance education was a necessity, not an end, that it surpassed expectations and that the ministry preferred live education. This is the plan with options for various education models for the autumn semester developed to ensure flexible implementation depending on the epidemiological situation. Plan considered and envisaged 110,000 tablets for elementary school students worth HRK 154.6 million and 26,755 laptops for teachers worth HRK 89 million.

description: On October 29, 2020, Science and Education Minister Radovan Fuchs said that closing schools and online classes would be the government's last resort and that he was not considering that measure for now. The school year starts in September, with schools being able to choose the mode of instruction (between physical, mixed and distance learning). Over 92% of schools chose the first mode, i.e. in-classroom, presence-based education. Also, kindergartens are closed because of stuff and positive Covid-19 results.

description: 13 January 2021, the Ministry of Education, the government of Croatia announced that following a prolonged winter break, the second school semester starts on 18 January, with new measures being introduced. Students in grades one to four of elementary school and the final grade of high school resumed physical learning, while all other students follow a distance learning mode. The beginning of the second semester in some schools in areas affected by the earthquake is further postponed.

description: As announced by the Croatian government back on December 23rd, 2020, the national vaccination program against Covid 19 began on December 27th, 2020 with the vaccine Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca, J&J, and  Moderna. The government was set to vaccinate most of its citizens by mid-2021, the health minister Beros said, furthermore the vaccine will be free of charge and given on a voluntary basis.     The vaccination plan is set in three phases and the Priority groups identified are:  *Healthcare professionals who are vaccinated in the first phase mean everyone in the healthcare system who comes into direct contact with patients, including pharmacists and non-healthcare professionals in healthcare facilities. And Vaccination of users and employees of homes for the elderly (and other institutions in the social welfare system) is planned in the Homes,    *2nd phase -Vaccination of persons over 65 years of age and patients with chronic diseases     *In the third phase, when vaccination will be offered to all interested parties,
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Regulatory approval process for administering the COVID-19 vaccine
type_vac_reg: Emergency regulatory approval or authorization granted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities,People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry),People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19

description: On 7 January 2021, Speaking at a cabinet meeting, Health Minister Vili Beros said on Thursday that 20,603 Croatians had been vaccinated against COVID to date, 7,611 were doctors and other medical professionals (37%) and 11,569 (56%) were beneficiaries of old-age care homes. Croatia has ordered a million doses of the Moderna vaccine, plus 2.7 million doses of the Oxford vaccine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 7 January 2021, Speaking at a cabinet meeting, Health Minister Vili Beros said on Thursday that 20,603 Croatians had been vaccinated against COVID to date, 7,611 were doctors and other medical professionals (37%) and 11,569 (56%) were beneficiaries of old-age care homes. Croatia has ordered a million doses of the Moderna vaccine, plus 2.7 million doses of the Oxford vaccine. The current vaccine that is being distributed is Pfizer/BioNTech. UPDATE: The original quarantine was set to last until January 11, it has been extended to  January 18, 2021.

description:
On February 5 2021, The Croatian Institute of Public Health prepared instructions/preparations for vaccination against COVID-19. Vaccinations in accordance with the EU, starting with groups A, and B: (initially with the Pfizer / BioNtech vaccine). Vaccines from the following manufacturers were ordered:
AstraZeneca/Oxford (adenovirus vector vaccine) – 2,700,000 doses
Johnson&Johnson/Janssen (adenovirus vector vaccine) – 900,000 doses
Pfizer/BioNTech (mRNA vaccine) – 1,000,000 doses
Moderna (mRNA vaccine) – 1,000,000 doses

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On February 22 2021 (updated day), The Croatian Institute of Public Health prepared instructions/preparations for vaccination against COVID-19. No change was found. Vaccinations in accordance with EU, starting with groups A, and B: (initially with the Pfizer / BioNtech vaccine). Given that all* vaccines are administered in two doses with different intervals, the quantity contracted so far is sufficient to vaccinate 2,800,000 inhabitants of the Republic of Croatia.
* except for the Janssen vaccine, for which there is a possibility of applying 1 dose .

description: On Monday, March 1, 2021, the Ministry of Health announced that all Croatian citizens and residents in Croatia can apply for vaccinations. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and time of vaccination to their email address, text message or phone, depending on the choice at check-in.  People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of younger age.

description: On April 3 2021, according to the Croatian Institute of Public Health, Croatia is participating in the European Commission’s joint procurement of the COVID-19 disease vaccine, and the vaccine will be available in Croatia at the same time as in other European Union countries. No change was found.   Vaccinations in accordance with EU, starting with groups A,B: (initially with the Pfizer / BioNtech vaccine). Effective January 26, all airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within three calendar days of travel.

description: On April 19, 2021, the Croatian government announced that vaccines available in Croatia are Pfizer–BioNTech, Moderna, and AstraZeneca. The primary target of the vaccination is the following: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly; 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases and 3) the rest of the population.    From March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and persons residing in Croatia can apply for vaccination via the cijepise.zdravlje.hr website or by phone at  0800 0011, where applications will be received and recorded in the central registration system. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and date of vaccination to their e-mail address, SMS or phone, depending on the choice at registration. People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of a younger age. Vaccination is carried out in family medicine surgeries, especially for chronic patients, in the  County Institutes of Public Health and at mass vaccination points.    Foreigners who are in Croatia as tourists cannot register for the vaccine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Regulatory approval process for administering the COVID-19 vaccine
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Foreigners who are in Croatia as tourists cannot register for the vaccine.

description: From April 20, 2021, According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.   Foreigners who are in Croatia as tourists cannot register for the vaccine. Vaccines available in Croatia are Pfizer–BioNTech, Moderna, and AstraZeneca. The primary target of the vaccination are the following: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly; 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases and 3) the rest of the population.    From March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and persons residing in Croatia can apply for vaccination via the cijepise.zdravlje.hr website or by phone at  0800 0011, where applications will be received and recorded in the central registration system. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and date of vaccination to their e-mail address, SMS or phone, depending on the choice at registration. People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of a younger age. Vaccination is carried out in family medicine surgeries, especially for chronic patients, in the  County Institutes of Public Health and at mass vaccination points.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Regulatory approval process for administering the COVID-19 vaccine
type_vac_reg: Emergency regulatory approval or authorization granted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 3, 2020, Croatia announced the Border Sanitary Inspector or the Sanitary Inspector of the Regional or Central Office of the State Inspectorate will have trucking companies complete questionnaires to confirm truckers are not ill and have not been in contact with someone infected with COVID-19. They will then be under health surveillance as long as the area the driver goes to or from is affected by COVID-19 and they have discussed their travels and health with an epidemiologist. Proof of this discussion with the epidemiologist is required upon returning to Croatia from an affected country to prove to the border patrol officer that the truck driver was already under surveillance.

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia banned transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding Croatian citizens and foreign nationals returning home, law enforcement, cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats, civil protection services and teams, staff of international organizations and international military personnel, and passengers in transit. Also excluded are citizens EU and Schengen zone residents as well as those with long-term residence and persons entitled to residence or national long-term visas. These individuals are allowed to return to their home countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia prohibited ships from entering Croatian ports if they have a quarantine requirement. Exceptions to this policy are all ships of Croatian nationality, all ships sailing in the Republic of Croatia for the transport of goods, passenger ships without passengers arriving in the Republic of Croatia for storage, and all ships entering the shipyards for repair. Entering ships and cargo may be subject to health inspection and disinfection, while individuals may face a sanitary health inspection. An extension, effective through May 18, 2020, was announced on April 19, 2020. This policy ended on April 26, 2020, when the cargo line Zadar - Acona was granted an exception to ship prohibition.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 9, 2020, Croatia stated EU citizens and all other nationals may enter Croatia if they have a business reason or other economic interest. They are also allowed to enter Croatia if they have any other reason that cannot be postponed (for example, because they own a property or a boat/yacht, as well as if they attend a funeral). The reason must also be provable, such as the possession of an invitation for a business appointment/meeting, a land register extract, proof of accommodation, marriage certificate, proof of boat/yacht ownership, etc. Travelers must not have visible COVID-19 symptoms to enter.

description: Starting May 11, 2020, Croatia stated people entering Croatia would no longer be required to self-isolate but would need to follow strict guidelines. They will be required to keep their contacts with other people to the minimum, spend as little time as possible outdoors and maintain hygiene. They are also advised to wear face masks and take their body temperature regularly. If they become symptomatic, Croatian nationals need to report to their GP while foreign nationals should contact the epidemiological service.

description: On July 1, 2020, the Croatian government temporarily prohibited entry into Croatia. Exempt from these restrictions are citizens of EU/EEA and Schengen member states, the UK, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Switzerland, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, the Vatican, Algeria, Australia, Montenegro, Georgia, Japan, South Korea, Canada, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, China (provided they eliminate restrictions on EU citizens), and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Additionally, health care professionals, cross-branch workers, transport operators, diplomats, those with economic interests (including tourism), and those traveling for schooling or other immediate personal reasons are exempt. Those arriving from exempt countries may enter freely. Travelers are, however, advised to fill out the form on the ENTERCROATIA web-page. All foreign nationals not exempt must provide relevant proof and meet any Croatian government requirements. On July 14, 2020, this measure was extended until July 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 23 June 2020, an Announcement from HZJZ regarding the stay of Prime Minister Andrej Plenković in Zadar was published with detailed information on what is permitted and accepted. the CNIPH published the official definition of close contact as a person who has been in face-to-face contact with a person infected with COVID-19 at a distance of fewer than two meters for more than 15 minutes; physical contact such as a hug, kiss, handshake or more intimate contact; a person who has been indoors with a person infected with COVID-19  e.g. household, classroom, meeting room, hospital waiting room, etc. for more than 15 minutes; unprotected contact with the bodily secretions of an infected person; caring for an infected person or handling the biological material of an infectious patient without the use of protective equipment; travel in the same means of transport with an infected person depending on the type of means of transport and distance. Any other type of contact is considered a low risk of infection, and persons making such contact are not subject to epidemiological self-isolation and testing measures
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: A person’s absolute (e.g. GPS) location over time

description: April 2, 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health announced that when a healthcare worker suspects a SARS-CoV-2 infection based on the above criteria, it is important to properly treat the patient clinically and carry out the necessary diagnostic workup. In the case of laboratory confirmation, the doctor who sent the sample for testing or concluded without testing that it is COVID-19 should immediately notify the territorially competent epidemiologist by phone and fill out the form Report of illness-death from an infectious disease immediately, no later than within 24 hours and submit it to the territorially competent epidemiologist. "However, in parts of Croatia where local disease transmission is established, suspicion of COVID-19 is raised on the basis of symptoms of the acute respiratory disease if the disease cannot be interpreted by another aetiology, whether or not the severity of the clinical picture requires hospitalization." (translated by Google Translate)

description:
On July 13 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health answered several questions regarding testing. The Croatian Health Insurance Institute (HZZO) pays for the testing of the coronavirus for all its insured persons, i.e. it pays for virus typing by molecular methods to contracted healthcare institutions of the HZZO.
In addition to testing, the HZZO ensures payment of health services in full for all health care related to infectious diseases for which the implementation of measures to prevent their spread is determined by law.

No idea what's Croatia's testing policy. They say they tested 640 people in one day which seems too low for testing to be really generally available.    This page says that public insurance covers COVID tests and costs

description: March 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health posted info about testing and who is on priority. Testing is targeted at symptomatic individuals and priority groups outlined here (unclear when this testing policy came into effect) Croatia's Public Health Center also notes that: "Testing for new coronavirus is not routinely performed in close contacts of a person with confirmed COVID-19 who has no signs of disease. The reason for this is that negative test results in such an asymptomatic phase do not rule out infection. Therefore, testing for SARS-CoV-2 is performed only in case of suspected COVID-19, ie when the clinical and epidemiological criteria of the disease are met."

description: On September 14 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior informed travellers to contact them after they got a negative PCR test. In addition, a test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia. After receiving a negative test locally, travellers will need to contact a local epidemiologist to clear them from self-isolation. Travelers whose test is older than 48 hours will be allowed to enter Croatia, but they will be issued a self-isolation order and will have to be tested again locally, at their own expense. Having an expired PCR test upon arrival will allow for a shortened period of time in self-isolation pending a negative result of a local PCR test. Those who do not provide a negative PCR test upon arrival will be ordered to quarantine/self-isolate for at least 7 days prior to taking a local PCR test. Travellers who fail to present a PCR test upon arrival and refuse to take a test locally will be ordered to self-isolate or quarantine for 14 days. A local test cost ranges from $130 to $300 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 24-48 hours.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 15 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health published Consolidated revised recommendations on priorities for testing for SARS-CoV-2, dealing with contacts, and ending isolation and quarantine/self-isolation with reference to persons who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated. In order to reduce the spread of infection, all close contacts of the patient are referred to health surveillance in quarantine self-isolation. Close contacts do not need to be tested either at the beginning or during quarantine self-isolation unless they develop symptoms of the disease if capacity allows or there is an epidemiological indication. Close contacts are subject to quarantine self-isolation health surveillance for 10 days from the last close contact with an infected person. Exceptionally, at the beginning of quarantine self-isolation, close contacts of COVID-19 patients should be tested if they have been identified as close contacts three or more days after exposure to the patient and have in the meantime made contact with vulnerable groups eg. working in a hospital or social service provider. accommodation and stay for elderly and seriously ill adults and people with disabilities. Upon completion of quarantine, it is not necessary to test individuals if they do not develop symptoms  unless they are immunocompromised.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description:
On January 20 2021, the government of Croatia made updates about health testing.   Effective January 26, all airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within three calendar days of travel. Alternatively, travellers to the U.S. may provide documentation from a licensed health care provider of having recovered from COVID-19 in the 90 days preceding travel.  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes
If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On January 29 2021, the government of Croatia published news on vaccines, including information for travellers too. According to the Croatian Institute of Public Health, Croatia is participating in the European Commission’s joint procurement of the COVID-19 disease vaccine, and the vaccine will be available in Croatia at the same time as in other European Union countries.  The current Vaccination Plan has three phases: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly (and other institutions that provide accommodation in the social welfare system) and health professionals, 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases, and 3) the rest of the population.  For more information about the Croatian government’s COVID-19 Vaccination Plan, visit the Croatian Institute of Public Health information page. Contact your local healthcare provider for information on how you may qualify for vaccination at this time.
Information from the CDC regarding COVID-19 vaccination.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

the exception to the need for testing and quarantine after recovering from an illness or vaccination is extended from three to six months.
so called. the British variant of SARS-CoV-2 has been removed from the list of variants for which the duration of the quarantine is 14 days and mandatory testing at the end of the quarantine.

description: On July 7 2021, in accordance with the instructions of the Ministry of Health, the work of separate clinics for the examination of patients suspected of coronavirus infection, the so-called covid-19 ambulances, is temporarily suspended. such a decision is prompted, in addition to the favourable epidemiological situation, by the weak interest of citizens in rapid antigen testing, as well as very high external temperatures at which it is not recommended to perform a rapid test. general/family physicians can perform rapid antigen tests in the office and enter the result of the test in the central covid-19 testing register used as a reference system for issuing EU digital covid certificates.

description: On July 15 2021,  the Croatian Institute of Public Health published updated its recommendation for testing. According to these, priority groups for testing are  a  Symptomatic persons who, due to their characteristics, primarily occupations, have a high potential spreading the disease to vulnerable groups  healthcare professionals and hospitalized patients, with signs and symptoms of acute respiratory infection, wards and employees of homes for the elderly and infirm and other social welfare institutions ; b  Symptomatic persons who, due to their characteristics, have a high potential for infecting a large number of people at risk of rapid spread of infection and cluster formation  prisoners and prison staff, refugees and asylum seekers, homeless people, members of ethnic   cultural groups whose lifestyle is conducive to the transmission of the disease by droplets and direct contact, etc. ; c  Symptomatic persons with increased risk of severe disease and complications  persons aged 65 years and older, persons with chronic diseases  diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, chronic lung diseases, immuno-compromised conditions, chronic kidney disease ; d  If a grouping of respiratory disease that cannot be interpreted by another etiology is observed in a health institution, it is necessary to test symptomatic persons;
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 22, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23, 2020. 

Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.

Passes will be required and signed by appropriate entities.

description: From March 21 2021, the government of Croatia decided to take measures such as wearing protective masks mandatory in all closed spaces throughout the country. Masks are also mandatory in open spaces where a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters cannot be maintained. In addition, individuals must maintain at least 2 meters of social distance indoors and at least 1.5 meters outdoors. Also, Private gatherings in homes are limited to 10 people from two households and must end at 22:00. And other kinds of strict measures such as no weddings and limited 25 people funerals are included.

New changes are the exception to the need for testing and quarantine after recovering from an illness or vaccination is extended from three to six months. The British variant of SARS-CoV-2 has been removed from the list of variants for which the duration of the quarantine is 14 days and mandatory testing at the end of the quarantine.

description: On April 12 2021, the official Croatian government website published updates about the number of infected once. 422 new cases in the past 24 hours, a total of 1,953 people in hospitals. In the past 24 hours, 422 new cases were recorded, so the number of active cases in Croatia today is a total of 11,844. Among them are 1,953 patients receiving hospital treatment, of which 191 patients are on ventilators. In the past 24 hours, 1,794 people recovered, and 3,201 of them were tested.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 19 2021, the official Croatian government response published 410 new cases in the past 24 hours, a total of 2,179 people in hospitals
In the past 24 hours, 410 new cases were recorded, so the number of active cases in Croatia today is a total of 13,812. Among them, there are 2,179 patients receiving hospital treatment, of which 199 patients are on ventilators. In the past 24 hours, 2,227 people recovered, and 2,728 of them were tested.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 30 2021, the Ministry of Health made the announcement on restrictions on mass gatherings and proposed some recommendations.  all persons in the territory of the Republic of Croatia are obliged to comply with strict physical distancing measures, all prescribed anti-epidemic measures, special recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public Health, and the necessary epidemiological measures prescribed by this decision. The Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures limiting gatherings and introducing other necessary epidemiological measures and recommendations to prevent the transmission of the COVID-19 disease through gatherings. Necessary epidemiological measures are set until May 15, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Gathering information related to COVID-19 from the public
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 7 2021, the Government of Croatia publishes the latest news on Covid-19 and related issues. there's a whole website containing information to the local population and also travellers regarding covid.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On July 14 2021,   the government publishes information on Coronavirus - statistical indicators for Croatia and the EU. 155 new cases in the past 24 hours, 16,396 doses of vaccine consumed
In the past 24 hours, 155 new cases were recorded, so the number of active cases in Croatia today is a total of 595. Among them, 111 patients are receiving hospital treatment, of which 8 patients are on ventilators. In the past 24 hours, 54 people recovered, and 3,965 of them were tested.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On July 21 2021, the government publishes information on Coronavirus - statistical indicators for Croatia and the EU. 191 new cases in the past 24 hours, 18,543 doses of vaccine consumed
In the past 24 hours, 191 new cases were recorded, so the number of active cases in Croatia today is a total of 838. Among them, 122 patients are receiving hospital treatment, of which 13 patients are on ventilators. In the past 24 hours, 91 people recovered, and 4,205 of them were tested.

description: On February 21, 2020 the Croatian Institute of Public Health initiated the quarantine of persons who were identified or suspected to have been in direct contact with patients with COVID-19 while on board ships. The designated quarantine unit is at the Infectious Diseases Clinic “Dr Fran Mihaljevic” in Zagreb.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On February 24, 2020, the Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health stated that for all persons who have been in close contact with a patient who has COVID-19, self-isolation is foreseen in their own home with daily contact with the epidemiologist or organized quarantine if there are no conditions for self-isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On February 24, 2020. the Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
All travelers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy. This policy ended on March 12, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 9, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers who drive to coronavirus affected areas must stay in self-isolation upon arrival in Croatia until they leave for the next transport. Upon their return, they are obliged to undergo self-isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: On March 12, 2020, Croatia announced that Drivers in cross-border traffic who enter the Republic of Croatia, except for drivers in transit, and come from areas affected by coronavirus, based on the decision of the sanitary inspection will be sent to self-isolation for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 16, 2020, Croatia announced that anyone disobeying the order to self-isolate or other measures imposed over the coronavirus outbreak faces a fine of HRK 8,000 (€1,060), while repeat offenders face a fine of up to HRK 120,000 (€16,000).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 9, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers who drive to coronavirus affected areas must stay in self-isolation upon arrival in Croatia until they leave for the next transport. Upon their return, they are obliged to undergo self-isolation. UPDATE: On March 20, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Health stated truck drivers will not leave their cabin for unloading goods. After unloading, drivers will quarantine in their homes or isolation organizes by their company. If organized by their company, they may break quarantine to return to work. They may not break quarantine if they are in their own homes or another private location.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: On March 26, 2020 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared to liberalize the procedure related to Croatian and foreign citizens that drive for Croatian employers in international transport. Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 9, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers who drive to coronavirus affected areas must stay in self-isolation upon arrival in Croatia until they leave for the next transport. Upon their return, they are obliged to undergo self-isolation. On March 20, 2020, Croatia stated after unloading, drivers will quarantine in their homes or isolation organizes by their company. description:
On April 17, Croatian Parliament, pursuant to Article 89 of the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia, enacted decision on the promulgation of the law on amendments to the law on protection of the population from infectious diseases. 

With new amendments, for the people who are suspected of suffering from COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus or healthy persons who have been in contact with persons suffering from the disease, or come from the area of the affected COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, health professionals may determine the isolation in their own home, or in another suitable space - a self-isolation, if appropriate conditions are met (Art. 8). 

Furthermore, for each violation of the provisions of this Act, the sanitary inspector of the State Inspectorate may, on the spot, charge a fine in the amount of HRK 5,000.00 (660 euros). (Art. 17).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 26 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared to liberalize the procedure related to Croatian and foreign citizens that drive for Croatian employers in international transport. Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors. UPDATE: As of May 7, 2020, Croatia stated the requirement for international goods drivers to quarantine upon arrival does not apply anymore.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 9, 2020, Croatia stated self-isolation is no longer required for all passengers at border crossings when entering the Republic of Croatia. It can only be assigned to individuals who are found by border control to have been in contact with a person with COVID-19. Individuals instructed to self-isolate prior to May 9th, 2020 must still comply with those instructions. Upon entering the Republic of Croatia, the border police hand over a leaflet with instructions and recommendations of the Croatian Institute of Public Health, which must be followed for the next 14 days. On June 25, 2020, Croatia introduced a mandatory self-isolation for individuals entering Croatia from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia, and Serbia with limited exceptions, ending this policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Effective May 11, 2020, Croatia announced people entering Croatia are no longer required to self-isolate, but must keep contacts with other people to a minimum, spend as little time as possible outdoors, and maintain hygiene. They are advised to wear face masks and take their body temperature regularly. If symptoms arise, Croatian nationals must report to their GP while foreign nationals should contact the epidemiological service.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 21,2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health initiated the quarantine of persons who were identified or suspected to have been in direct contact with patients with COVID-19 while on board ships. The designated quarantine unit is at the Infectious Diseases Clinic “Dr Fran Mihaljevic” in Zagreb. UPDATE: Effective May 11, 2020, Croatia stated people entering the country are no longer required to self-isolate but would still need to follow strict guidelines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On June 25, 2020, Croatian Civil Protection Headquarters introduced mandatory self-isolation for people entering Croatia from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia and Serbia. There are exceptions for those who, due to the nature of their work and living circumstances, will not have to isolate themselves, and among them are cross-border workers and those transiting through these four countries and through Croatia. Additionally, those crossing for a funeral, medical care, or transport will not be subjected to this rule.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Beginning July 1, 2020, Croatia ended the self-isolation measures for passengers arriving to the nation. On July 10, 2020, this policy ended when Croatia announced a mandatory quarantine for those arriving without a PCR test or with an expired test (older than 48 hours).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Beginning July 11, 2020, Croatia announced a mandatory 14-day quarantine for those arriving to Croatia without a PCR test. They will have the option of quarantining for at least 7 days prior to taking a local PCR test. Upon receiving a negative test, they must contact a local epidemiologist to clear them from self-isolation. Those who refuse to take a test locally will be ordered to self-isolate or quarantine for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Beginning July 11, 2020, Croatia announced those arriving with an expired PCR test must quarantine and must be tested again locally at their own expense. An expired PCR test will allow for a shortened period of self-isolation (7 days), pending a negative result of a local PCR test.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Mar 14 Istria County his shuttering all hospitality businesses for the next month in a move to try and curb the spread of the coronavirus. All cafes and restaurants will be closed until April 14. Food delivery services and soup kitchens are exempt but are under strict cautionary measures, said Damir Kozlovac, the head of county civil defense services.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On March 21, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has adopted a new set of measures, according to which taxi service providers' employers are obliged to inform and educate employees about the disease itself and recommendations/ general and specific protection measures.

Employers are obliged to ensure working conditions that include sufficient amounts of soap and disposable towels in the sanitary facilities, regular cleaning of the premises with disinfectants, and to organize the normal functioning of business processes in the company's premises (with larger taxi carriers and in call centres).

Taxi service providers are also obliged to have the measures prescribed by this Decision displayed in a visible place in their vehicles that they provide services.

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which stores and establishments which are allowed to continue to operate in accordance with the restrictions are obliged to sell all bulk goods packaged, ensure that there are no crowds when entering shops and facilities, and organize work in such a way as to ensure the greatest possible distance between workers while respecting strict measures of social distance. UPDATE: On 19 March, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has adopted a new decision on measures to restrict social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events, except for some stores and establishments. On 18 April, this Decision has been extended until 4 May, 2020.

description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Maximum number of employees

description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Maximum number of employees

description:
On March 19 the Croatian government ordered the suspension of all businesses for 30 days with the exception of grocery stores, food and hygiene items, market and fish markets, specialized stores selling and dispensing (pharmacies), specialized stores selling and dispensing veterinary medicinal products, agricultural pharmacies, gas stations, kiosks, bakery, chemical laundry, specialized stores selling orthopedic and other aids, specialized baby equipment stores, specialized animal feed stores, issuance of construction materials based on retail order
logistic and distribution centers for food, beverages and hygiene products and wholesalers. UPDATE: On April 27, the Croatian government permitted shops to open, except those operating within big shopping centers and those in the service sector with close contact.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On April 30, 2020, Croatian Institute of Public Health issued the following recommendations for the work of physiotherapists in outpatient clinics and massage parlors, tattoo and piercing salons, and manicure and pedicure salons during the COVID-19 epidemic: indoor dispensers with hand disinfectant must be available and a notice on the obligation to disinfect the hands clearly indicated; the notice of the obligation to maintain a distance of at least two meters between persons should also be clearly stated at the entrance.

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which stores and establishments which are allowed to continue to operate in accordance with the restrictions are obliged to sell all bulk goods packaged, ensure that there are no crowds when entering shops and facilities, and organize work in such a way as to ensure the greatest possible distance between workers while respecting strict measures of social distance. UPDATE: On May 10, 2020, it was announced that of Monday, May 11, 2020, the decision of the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia on the necessary measures to limit social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events will change and the sectors will reopen.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which employers are required to organize work from home where possible, cancel meetings or organize teleconferences and use other technologies to hold remote meetings, cancel business trips outside the country except as necessary and prohibit entry into workplaces of workers who have fever and respiratory distress, especially dry cough and shortness of breath. UPDATE: On May 10, 2020, it was announced that of Monday, May 11, 2020, the decision of the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia on the necessary measures to limit social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events will change and the sectors will reopen.

description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection. UPDATE: On May 10, 2020, the Croatian government has announced that all training grounds and gyms can work from May 13, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Maximum number of employees

description: On June 7, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on amending the Decision on working hours and the way of operation of trade activities for the duration of the declared epidemic of the disease COVID-19, which abolished the mandatory one-hour break between two shifts for the purpose of changing workers and cleaning and disinfecting the premises for stores that work twice. The Headquarters still recommends that cleaning and disinfection of store premises be carried out regularly in accordance with the recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute of Public Health.

description: On August 10, 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health announced that multiplexes in shopping malls can reopen, five months after closing. At the entrance to the cinema area and in the interior, there should be means for hand disinfection and a notice that hand disinfection is mandatory. When it comes to cinema staff, they must measure their temperature every day before coming to work, and if it is higher than 37.2 degrees, they must not come to work. It is also recommended that visitors take their temperature before coming to the cinema. HZJZ points out that film screening is possible only in halls that can meet conditions such as maintaining physical distance. Also, the number of people who can be in the hall at the same time must be limited, and this number is determined by the organizer according to the size of the space and the type of event. A distance of at least 1.5 meters between visitors is recommended between each seat, as well as when entering, moving and exiting. The exit of visitors should be organized so that they exit one by one, and those closest to the door exit first. Organizers must keep records of visitors, and online ticket sales are encouraged to avoid physical contact.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Maximum number of employees,Temperature Check,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description: On Sunday, October 25, 2020, Croatia’s COVID-19 crisis management team presented a new set of restrictions that start from Monday the 26th: particular protocols are specified for plays and cultural programmes, film screenings in cinemas, religious rites, exhibitions in museums and similar events. Workers with a high body temperature and problems in their respiratory systems are required not to go to work. Also working from home, if possible, is recommended. The authorities have banned the sale of alcohol from midnight to 6 AM. The measures are set to last 14 days.

Workers with a high body temperature and problems in their respiratory systems are required not to go to work. Also working from home, if possible, is recommended. The authorities have banned the sale of alcohol from midnight to 6 AM. The measures are set to last 14 days.

description: In view of new instructions by the Croatian Institute for Public Health, since November 22, 2020, employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce work from home, when possible given the nature of the work; introduce sliding working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description: On November 22, 2020, Croatian government introduced new country-wide measures, including the obligation for all shops, stores, and catering facilities to clearly display at the entrance the notice of the largest possible number of customers who can be in the store at the same time in accordance with the recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute of Public Health and strict adherence to the permitted number of customers; obligation for all stores, shops and shopping centers to take additional measures during the expected arrival of a large number of customers (discounts, rebates, pre-holiday purchases, etc.) so that more customers do not stay in their premises at the same time and to ensure compliance epidemiological measures; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On November 22, 2020, Croatian government introduced new country-wide measures, including the obligation for all shops, stores, and catering facilities to clearly display at the entrance the notice of the largest possible number of customers who can be in the store at the same time in accordance with the recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute of Public Health and strict adherence to the permitted number of customers; obligation for all stores, shops and shopping centers to take additional measures during the expected arrival of a large number of customers (discounts, rebates, pre-holiday purchases, etc.) so that more customers do not stay in their premises at the same time and to ensure compliance epidemiological measures; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM. UPDATE: Croatian officials announced new COVID-19 measures to help mitigate the spread of the virus. As of 12:00 AM on November 28, the following measures will apply until December 21. Restaurants and cafes will be closed. All amateur plays, concerts, programs, practice, workshops, and dance schools are closed. Catering facilities in hotels and camps are permitted to serve their guests. Food delivery and drive-thrus are permitted, and bakeries may remain open until 10:00 pm. Gyms, fitness, recreation centers are closed. Foreign language schools may only operate online. Alcohol will not be sold from 10:00pm to 6:00am. It is now mandatory to wear a face covering in the following situations: shoppers/customers in stores; clients where face to face contact is required; all services that require close contact (hairdressers, salons, etc.); customers in all hospitality services who serve and prepare beverages and food, except while sitting in their seats and consuming food, drinks or beverages.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description: Since 12 December, 2020, new restrictions for shops and shopping centres will be implemented, as announced by the Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic. Shops and shopping centres will have to ensure 10 to 20 square metres of space per customer, depending on the size of the net sales area. Under the new decision, shops with a net sales area of less than 10 square metres will be able to admit only one customer at a time. Shops that have a net sales area of 11 to 100 square metres will have to ensure at least 10 square metres of space per customer. Shops with a net sales area of 101 to 200 square metres will have to provide at least 12 square metres of space per customer, those with a net sales area of 201 to 2,000 square metres will have to provide at least 16 square metres, and all shops with a net sales area of more than 2,000 square metres will have to ensure at least 20 square metres of space per customer. In shopping centres, the maximum number of customers will be determined by ensuring at least 16 square metres of space per customer, and all shops and shopping centres will be required to display a notice with the maximum number of customers that can be inside at the same time at the entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers,Size of store limited (e.g. stores smaller than 800 sq meters)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On November 20, 2020, the Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection published a decision on temporary regulation of work and limitation of working hours of catering facilities and other providers of catering services. Catering facilities can only operate from 6 AM to 10 PM nationwide starting from November 22.The stated working hours also apply to providers of catering services in the household and family farms, except for accommodation services. The stated working hours do not refer to catering facilities from the groups Hotels, Camps and Other catering facilities for accommodation, except for catering facilities of other groups that work in their composition. UPDATE: On December 21, 2020, The Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia suspended the operation of catering establishments and the provision of catering services on family farms, except for catering establishments from the groups "Hotels", "Camps" and the types of Učenički or Studentski dom or Akademis from the group "Other catering establishments for accommodation", which may only serve guests who use the accommodation service in them, i.e. pupils or students. As an exception to this anti-epidemic measure, catering facilities from the "Restaurants" group, "Catering facilities" group and types of cafes, pubs, buffets, taverns, taverns and cellars from the "Bars" group are allowed to prepare and deliver food and drinks. The aforementioned catering establishments can deliver food in compliance with all anti-epidemic measures in one of the following ways:
    -by personal pick-up at the entrance to the catering facility without entering the same
    -delivery of food from the restaurant with its own delivery vehicle
    -delivery of food from a catering facility based on a business cooperation agreement concluded between the caterer and a third party (legal or natural-artisan), who are registered and entered in the Register of Food Business Entities
    -by the so-called "drive in" method.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On December 21, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures, according to which there will be limitation of opening hours for bakeries and bread and bakery shops up until 10 PM; prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages from 10 PM to 6 AM; suspension of gyms, fitness centers and sports and recreation centers. The measures also include the suspension of children's and other workshops and organized dance schools; foreign language schools can only perform their activities online or in another way to maintain contact at a distance. Driving schools can hold the theoretical part only online or in another way to maintain contacts at a distance: driving lessons can last a maximum of 45 minutes with mandatory body temperature measurement before entering the car, a break between two candidates must be a minimum of 10 minutes for airing and disinfecting the car, and records of all participants in driving lessons must be kept. The measures are set to last until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Temperature Check
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 21, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures, according to which there will be limitation of opening hours for bakeries and bread and bakery shops up until 10 PM; prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages from 10 PM to 6 AM; suspension of gyms, fitness centers and sports and recreation centers. The measures also include the suspension of children's and other workshops and organized dance schools; foreign language schools can only perform their activities online or in another way to maintain contact at a distance. Driving schools can hold the theoretical part only online or in another way to maintain contacts at a distance: driving lessons can last a maximum of 45 minutes with mandatory body temperature measurement before entering the car, a break between two candidates must be a minimum of 10 minutes for airing and disinfecting the car, and records of all participants in driving lessons must be kept. The measures are set to last until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: In view of new instructions by the Croatian Institute for Public Health, since November 22, 2020, employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce work from home, when possible given the nature of the work; introduce sliding working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside. UPDATE: The necessary epidemiological measures were extended on December 21, 2020, by the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description: As announced by the Croatian government, starting February 15, 2021, bars and restaurants will be allowed to open for outdoor service, and gyms and fitness centres will be permitted to operate but must comply with the epidemiological measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Fitness centres and gyms need to provide at least 20 square metres per person at one time and the premises must be ventilated and equipment needs to be sanitised between users. Dressing rooms and showers must not be used. Casinos and other gambling venues will also be allowed to work until 10 PM; the number of visitors needs to be restricted to ensure at least 7 square metres per person. Hospitality sections of casinos and gaming rooms are to remain shut. Cafes will be permitted to sell drinks to go. All caterers can provide deliveries of food, drinks, beverages and sweets to go. People receiving food and beverages from hospitality establishments must not linger on terraces or in front of the provider’s premises or enter inside. People waiting for deliveries need to keep their distance and wear a mask. The containment measures will be revised on March 1, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Delivery and Takeaway Only
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Starting 1 April, 2021, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia have adopted new epidemiological measures. These include: limitation of working hours for bakeries and shops for bread and bakery products until 10 PM; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM; restricting the operation of catering facilities and family farms that provide catering services in such a way that food, drinks, beverages and sweets can be served only on open terraces or other open service areas, with strict adherence to instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public health, and working hours from 6 AM to 10 PM. Hospitality establishments can deliver food, drinks, beverages and desserts in compliance with all anti-epidemic measures in one of the following ways:
            by personal pick-up at the entrance to the catering facility without entering the same
            by delivery from the restaurant with its own delivery vehicle
            delivery from a catering establishment based on a business cooperation agreement concluded between the caterer and a third party (legal or natural-artisans), who are registered and entered in the Register of Entities in the Food Business
            by the so-called "drive in" method.

The working hours of casinos, club vending machines and payment points for betting may be determined from 8 AM to 10 PM, with a ban on the provision of catering services on their premises. The measures will last till June 30, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting 1 April, 2021, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia have adopted new epidemiological measures. These include: limitation of working hours for bakeries and shops for bread and bakery products until 10 PM; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM; restricting the operation of catering facilities and family farms that provide catering services in such a way that food, drinks, beverages and sweets can be served only on open terraces or other open service areas, with strict adherence to instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public health, and working hours from 6 AM to 10 PM. Hospitality establishments can deliver food, drinks, beverages and desserts in compliance with all anti-epidemic measures in one of the following ways:
            by personal pick-up at the entrance to the catering facility without entering the same
            by delivery from the restaurant with its own delivery vehicle
            delivery from a catering establishment based on a business cooperation agreement concluded between the caterer and a third party (legal or natural-artisans), who are registered and entered in the Register of Entities in the Food Business
            by the so-called "drive in" method.

The working hours of casinos, club vending machines and payment points for betting may be determined from 8 AM to 10 PM, with a ban on the provision of catering services on their premises. The measures will last till June 30, 2021. UPDATE: As of 2 July 2021, restaurants can offer food and beverages for takeout/delivery and may also serve guests seated both indoors and in an open-air space. Coffee shops and bars can only serve guests in open-air spaces. Nightclubs are closed. Casinos and betting shops are now open from 8 AM until 11 PM. Alcohol will not be sold from 11 PM to 6 AM.

Coffee shops and bars can only serve guests in open-air spaces. Nightclubs are closed. Casinos and betting shops are now open from 8 AM until 11 PM. Alcohol will not be sold from 11 PM to 6 AM.

description:
Starting 1 April, 2021, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia have adopted new epidemiological measures. These include: limitation of working hours for bakeries and shops for bread and bakery products until 10 PM; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM; restricting the operation of catering facilities and family farms that provide catering services in such a way that food, drinks, beverages and sweets can be served only on open terraces or other open service areas, with strict adherence to instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public health, and working hours from 6 AM to 10 PM. Hospitality establishments can deliver food, drinks, beverages and desserts in compliance with all anti-epidemic measures in one of the following ways:
            by personal pick-up at the entrance to the catering facility without entering the same
            by delivery from the restaurant with its own delivery vehicle
            delivery from a catering establishment based on a business cooperation agreement concluded between the caterer and a third party (legal or natural-artisans), who are registered and entered in the Register of Entities in the Food Business
            by the so-called "drive in" method.

The working hours of casinos, club vending machines and payment points for betting may be determined from 8 AM to 10 PM, with a ban on the provision of catering services on their premises. The measures will last till June 30, 2021. UPDATE: As of 2 July 2021, restaurants can offer food and beverages for takeout/delivery and may also serve guests seated both indoors and in an open-air space. Coffee shops and bars can only serve guests in open-air spaces. Nightclubs are closed. Casinos and betting shops are now open from 8 AM until 11 PM. Alcohol will not be sold from 11 PM to 6 AM.

description: As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures: curfew at midnight for all objects, including grocery stores and bakeries. In addition to delivery, drive-in or take-away, restaurants, catering facilities, cafés and bars may also serve guests outside (from 6 AM to 12 AM) and indoors. The number of guests in catering establishments should be limited so that a minimum distance of 1.5 m between guests can be ensured; disinfectants should be made available for the guests. Betting shops, casinos and slot machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 AM to 12 AM, but without serving food/drinks. No alcoholic beverages may be sold between 12 AM and 6 AM. The retail shops are open from 8 AM to 9 PM (until 11 PM at the latest). Masks are compulsory for all employees and customers; all shops must provide disinfectants to customers. Shops are obliged to indicate the maximum number of people allowed at the entrance (based on at least 10m²/person). Hairdressers, massage parlors, locksmiths, etc. are allowed to work in compliance with masks, disinfectants, disinfection of the premises, transparent barriers, etc. The same measures apply to hotels; they should ensure physical distancing of at least 1.5m among guests. Conditions for fitness centres: 20 m² per person, disinfection of the equipment after each use, customers must bring their own towels and mats, showers remain closed, distance rules must be strictly observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
