description:
As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures.
    Employers must prohibit all employees with a high body temperature, breathing difficulties, especially dry cough and shortness of breath, from coming to work; introducing home office, flexitime or work in shifts or groups and to reduce the number of physical meetings whenever possible; post important safety regulations, hygiene and health instructions in the offices; ensure sufficient protective equipment such as gloves, masks, protective suits, helmets, etc. Installation of physical barriers (plexiglass and similar barriers to reduce employee contact with customers); ensuring a place for disinfecting hands; ensuring through better distribution of space and working hours that the minimum distance between employees is guaranteed; meetings only with fewer than 5 people (if possible meeting online, by email or by phone); during breaks, making sure employees do not sit together in groups. Disinfection and cleaning of the work premises (all contact surfaces at least twice a day); regular airing of the rooms, special protection for employees with chronic illnesses and cancer (work from home office), etc. 

Additional regulations for construction: limit all indoor construction meetings to a minimum; divide construction workers into several groups that physically separate the groups; the tasks of building supervision also form groups; draw up evacuation plans; move unneeded people to home office.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Construction") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of working hours for employees (e.g. work at home policies),Maximum size of business meetings,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Effective March 22, 2020, the Croatian national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by tram, for the next 30 days. This measure includes:  public passenger transport by road within the country (except for taxi services), international public passenger transport by road, passenger transport by rail, tram and other city public transportation, as well as all other types of public transportation (such as funicular railway). This policy ended on May 11, 2020, when the government allowed intercity road, rail transport, and other forms of public transportation to resume in accordance with the regulations announced April 27, 2020.

description: On 22 December, 2020, according to the measures taken by the national government, the Croatian national postal service HP suspended deliveries to the United Kingdom until further notice following the discovery of a new, more contagious strain of the coronavirus in that country. UPDATE: The Croatian Post (HP) stated on Tuesday, 12 January, 2021 that the postal traffic between Croatia and the United Kingdom had resumed after its suspension on 22 December, 2020. Twenty days ago, the Croatian national postal service HP suspended deliveries to the United Kingdom until further notice following the discovery of a new, more contagious strain of the coronavirus in that country. HP said today that the deliveries had been resumed on 11 January. HP also underscores that since 1 January 2021, the United Kingdom has been treated as a third country, that is a country outside the European Union, and this impacts the customs treatment of deliveries to and from that country.

description: On March 20, 2020, Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals. The obituary must not contain information on the place and time of the funeral, the last funeral and the laying of the urn. The organization of music, flower, and candle delivery services are suspended. UPDATE: Effective May 29, 2020, Croatia revoked the limitations on funerals, including guest restrictions. description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 30, 2020, Croatian Institute of Public Health issued the following recommendations for the work of physiotherapists in outpatient clinics and massage parlors, tattoo and piercing salons, and manicure and pedicure salons during the COVID-19 epidemic: indoor dispensers with hand disinfectant must be available and a notice on the obligation to disinfect the hands clearly indicated; the notice of the obligation to maintain a distance of at least two meters between persons should also be clearly stated at the entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which stores and establishments which are allowed to continue to operate in accordance with the restrictions are obliged to sell all bulk goods packaged, ensure that there are no crowds when entering shops and facilities, and organize work in such a way as to ensure the greatest possible distance between workers while respecting strict measures of social distance. UPDATE: On May 10, 2020, it was announced that of Monday, May 11, 2020, the decision of the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia on the necessary measures to limit social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events will change and the sectors will reopen.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 27, 2020, Croatia announced nursing home patients are only allowed to leave the facility in necessary and justified circumstances such as going to the hospital for necessary and urgent health procedures. UPDATE: On May 11, 2020, Croatia stated nursing home patients may take walk and be in nature, independently or accompanied by professionals, depending on the age and condition assessment, but must remain on the property.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on patients leaving nursing home/long term care facility
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection. UPDATE: On May 10, 2020, the Croatian government has announced that all training grounds and gyms can work from May 13, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 14, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued recommendations of social distancing for visitors at  beaches as well as freshwater and sea swimming areas. These recommendations include  a maximum number of 15 people per one hundred square meters on the beaches and maintaining 1.5 m physical distance between individuals in the water.

description: On May 18, 2020, the operation of theaters resumed with strict hygienic and distancing measures. The space must be regularly disinfected. There also must be physical distancing of 1.5 metres between visitors and 4 metres between the public and the performers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 27, 2020, Croatia banned visits to homes for the elderly and infirm. UPDATE: On May 18, 2020, Croatia stated nursing home residents may have visitors and the visitors must comply with epidemiological measures. A maximum of one visitor per room is allowed with strict adherence to measures (mandatory hand disinfection, protective mask), with prior body temperature measurement and signing a statement that the visitor has no symptoms of COVID-19, is not in self-isolation and that his family has no respiratory symptoms. Registration of all visitors on arrival and departure is mandatory.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: On April 24, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued a recommendation for drivers of public transportation (buses and trams) to wear masks. This policy was updated on June 25 which required both drivers and passengers in public transportation to wear masks. UPDATE: Originally on April 24, the Croatian Institute of Public health recommended drivers of public transportation to wear masks. However, this policy was updated on June 25, making it mandatory for both passengers and drivers to wear a mask.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 10, 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health announced that multiplexes in shopping malls can reopen, five months after closing. At the entrance to the cinema area and in the interior, there should be means for hand disinfection and a notice that hand disinfection is mandatory. When it comes to cinema staff, they must measure their temperature every day before coming to work, and if it is higher than 37.2 degrees, they must not come to work. It is also recommended that visitors take their temperature before coming to the cinema. HZJZ points out that film screening is possible only in halls that can meet conditions such as maintaining physical distance. Also, the number of people who can be in the hall at the same time must be limited, and this number is determined by the organizer according to the size of the space and the type of event. A distance of at least 1.5 meters between visitors is recommended between each seat, as well as when entering, moving and exiting. The exit of visitors should be organized so that they exit one by one, and those closest to the door exit first. Organizers must keep records of visitors, and online ticket sales are encouraged to avoid physical contact.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: August 24, 2020, School starts in Croatia on September 7, the Education Ministry said on Monday that the main rule is to keep one's distance, not to mix pupils from different classes and to step up hygiene, while face masks will be mandatory only for pupils in higher grades if there is not enough space for them to keep their distance. Pupils should come into contact with a few teachers as possible during one day or period. If there are no other possibilities, it is suggested that the school operates in shifts. For instance, half of the classes could attend school for one week, and the second half next week. In the event of a child exhibiting symptoms, he or she is separated from others and parents come to pick up their child, but there is no need to panic, and an epidemiologist should only be contacted if several children start showing symptoms. If a child tests positive for COVID-19, the entire class or kindergarten group will undergo self-isolation. classes in lower grades of primary school would follow the bubble model so pupils will not leave the classroom, they will have controlled access to the toilet, their teacher will be with them all the time and they will not mix with children from other classes. They will not have to wear face masks, nor will their teacher. Pupils in higher grades of primary schools will only have to wear masks if there is not enough space for them to maintain physical distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 29, 2020, Science and Education Minister Radovan Fuchs said that closing schools and online classes would be the government's last resort and that he was not considering that measure for now. The school year starts in September, with schools being able to choose the mode of instruction (between physical, mixed and distance learning). Over 92% of schools chose the first mode, i.e. in-classroom, presence-based education. Also, kindergartens are closed because of stuff and positive Covid-19 results.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Over 92% of schools chose the first mode, i.e. in-classroom, presence-based education. Also, kindergartens are closed because of stuff and positive Covid-19 results. UPDATE: The original quarantine was set to last until October 26, then it has been extended to October 27. Finally, it finished with October 30.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In view of new instructions by the Croatian Institute for Public Health, since November 22, 2020, employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce work from home, when possible given the nature of the work; introduce sliding working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Croatian officials announced new COVID-19 measures to help mitigate the spread of the virus. As of 12:00 AM on November 28, 2020, the following measures will apply until December 21, 2020. It is now mandatory to wear a face covering in the following situations: Retail employees in stores; employees where face to face contact is required; all services that require close contact (hairdressers, salons, etc.); employees of all hospitality services who serve and prepare beverages and food; employees in offices where a physical distance of at least 2 meters cannot be maintained.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Since 12 December, 2020, new restrictions for shops and shopping centres will be implemented, as announced by the Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic. Shops and shopping centres will have to ensure 10 to 20 square metres of space per customer, depending on the size of the net sales area. Under the new decision, shops with a net sales area of less than 10 square metres will be able to admit only one customer at a time. Shops that have a net sales area of 11 to 100 square metres will have to ensure at least 10 square metres of space per customer. Shops with a net sales area of 101 to 200 square metres will have to provide at least 12 square metres of space per customer, those with a net sales area of 201 to 2,000 square metres will have to provide at least 16 square metres, and all shops with a net sales area of more than 2,000 square metres will have to ensure at least 20 square metres of space per customer. In shopping centres, the maximum number of customers will be determined by ensuring at least 16 square metres of space per customer, and all shops and shopping centres will be required to display a notice with the maximum number of customers that can be inside at the same time at the entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18th December 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures limiting gatherings and introducing other necessary epidemiological measures and recommendations to prevent the transmission of the COVID-19 disease through gatherings. Necessary epidemiological measures are set until February 15, 2021. The strict physical distancing measure mandates avoiding close personal contact at a distance of at least 2 meters indoors and 1.5 meters outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 21, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures, according to which there will be limitation of opening hours for bakeries and bread and bakery shops up until 10 PM; prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages from 10 PM to 6 AM; suspension of gyms, fitness centers and sports and recreation centers. The measures also include the suspension of children's and other workshops and organized dance schools; foreign language schools can only perform their activities online or in another way to maintain contact at a distance. Driving schools can hold the theoretical part only online or in another way to maintain contacts at a distance: driving lessons can last a maximum of 45 minutes with mandatory body temperature measurement before entering the car, a break between two candidates must be a minimum of 10 minutes for airing and disinfecting the car, and records of all participants in driving lessons must be kept. The measures are set to last until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As announced by the Croatian government, starting February 15, 2021, bars and restaurants will be allowed to open for outdoor service, and gyms and fitness centres will be permitted to operate but must comply with the epidemiological measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Fitness centres and gyms need to provide at least 20 square metres per person at one time and the premises must be ventilated and equipment needs to be sanitised between users. Dressing rooms and showers must not be used. Casinos and other gambling venues will also be allowed to work until 10 PM; the number of visitors needs to be restricted to ensure at least 7 square metres per person. Hospitality sections of casinos and gaming rooms are to remain shut. Cafes will be permitted to sell drinks to go. All caterers can provide deliveries of food, drinks, beverages and sweets to go. People receiving food and beverages from hospitality establishments must not linger on terraces or in front of the provider’s premises or enter inside. People waiting for deliveries need to keep their distance and wear a mask. The containment measures will be revised on March 1, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Starting 1 April, 2021, the Croatian Institute for Public Health has adopted a decision according to which employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce flexible working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers stay. The decision is set to be in place until 30 June, 2021.

description: As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures: curfew at midnight for all objects, including grocery stores and bakeries. In addition to delivery, drive-in or take-away, restaurants, catering facilities, cafés and bars may also serve guests outside (from 6 AM to 12 AM) and indoors. The number of guests in catering establishments should be limited so that a minimum distance of 1.5 m between guests can be ensured; disinfectants should be made available for the guests. Betting shops, casinos and slot machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 AM to 12 AM, but without serving food/drinks. No alcoholic beverages may be sold between 12 AM and 6 AM. The retail shops are open from 8 AM to 9 PM (until 11 PM at the latest). Masks are compulsory for all employees and customers; all shops must provide disinfectants to customers. Shops are obliged to indicate the maximum number of people allowed at the entrance (based on at least 10m²/person). Hairdressers, massage parlors, locksmiths, etc. are allowed to work in compliance with masks, disinfectants, disinfection of the premises, transparent barriers, etc. The same measures apply to hotels; they should ensure physical distancing of at least 1.5m among guests. Conditions for fitness centres: 20 m² per person, disinfection of the equipment after each use, customers must bring their own towels and mats, showers remain closed, distance rules must be strictly observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

The number of guests in catering establishments should be limited so that a minimum distance of 1.5 m between guests can be ensured; disinfectants should be made available for the guests. Betting shops, casinos and slot machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 AM to 12 AM, but without serving food/drinks. No alcoholic beverages may be sold between 12 AM and 6 AM. The retail shops are open from 8 AM to 9 PM (until 11 PM at the latest). Masks are compulsory for all employees and customers; all shops must provide disinfectants to customers. Shops are obliged to indicate the maximum number of people allowed at the entrance (based on at least 10m²/person). Hairdressers, massage parlors, locksmiths, etc. are allowed to work in compliance with masks, disinfectants, disinfection of the premises, transparent barriers, etc. The same measures apply to hotels; they should ensure physical distancing of at least 1.5m among guests. Conditions for fitness centres: 20 m² per person, disinfection of the equipment after each use, customers must bring their own towels and mats, showers remain closed, distance rules must be strictly observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures.
    Employers must prohibit all employees with a high body temperature, breathing difficulties, especially dry cough and shortness of breath, from coming to work; introducing home office, flexitime or work in shifts or groups and to reduce the number of physical meetings whenever possible; post important safety regulations, hygiene and health instructions in the offices; ensure sufficient protective equipment such as gloves, masks, protective suits, helmets, etc. Installation of physical barriers (plexiglass and similar barriers to reduce employee contact with customers); ensuring a place for disinfecting hands; ensuring through better distribution of space and working hours that the minimum distance between employees is guaranteed; meetings only with fewer than 5 people (if possible meeting online, by email or by phone); during breaks, making sure employees do not sit together in groups. Disinfection and cleaning of the work premises (all contact surfaces at least twice a day); regular airing of the rooms, special protection for employees with chronic illnesses and cancer (work from home office), etc. 

Additional regulations for construction: limit all indoor construction meetings to a minimum; divide construction workers into several groups that physically separate the groups; the tasks of building supervision also form groups; draw up evacuation plans; move unneeded people to home office.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Construction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Amendments from June 9, 2021, Hrvatski zavod za javno zdravstvo announced that Schools are open, but with strict guidelines (e.g. splitting classes into two shifts) and some offer a mixture of classroom and online teaching. It includes measures on physical distance, hand hygiene, hand disinfection, organization of space, temperature measurement and symptom monitoring etc.  (published or made editions on July 14)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
